resolutions.notes: Minor variation - 'I want to' is more complete and works in all contexts. 'I want' alone is incomplete without an object.

upchunks.teaches: 期待 (look forward to) triggers gerund form in English
'say' is used for specific words/phrases; 'speak' is for the act of speaking

resolutions.notes: Base form is 'to speak'. Context determines: 'say' for specific utterances, 'speaking' after gerund-triggering verbs.
Both 'now' and 'at the moment' are valid translations. Standardize to 'now' as it's more common and versatile. 'At the moment' is a stylistic choice, not linguistically triggered.

No upchunking needed. The English case (I/me) is determined by grammatical position in the English sentence, not by Chinese context. Subject position = 'I', object position = 'me'. This is taught at the sentence level, not the LEGO level.

upchunks.teaches: Progressive/continuous aspect in English uses -ing form with 'been'
When 'learning' is the subject of a sentence, use gerund form

resolutions.notes: Base infinitive 'to learn'. Gerund 'learning' used as subject or after certain verbs.

upchunks.teaches: 'speak' is used for the general ability/activity; 'say' is for specific words

resolutions.notes: 'How to say' is the default for asking about specific words/phrases. 'How to speak' is less common and refers to the manner of speaking.

upchunks.teaches: 练习 (practise) triggers gerund form in English
停止 (stop) triggers gerund form; 'talking' often used for informal/casual speech
开始 (start) can trigger either infinitive or gerund; 'talking' for casual speech
能够 (be able) triggers infinitive form
想 (want) triggers infinitive form

resolutions.notes: This is the most complex conflict. Base form 'to speak'. Gerund triggers: 练习, 停止, 开始. Infinitive triggers: 能够, 想. 'Talking' is often used interchangeably with 'speaking' for casual conversation.

upchunks.teaches: After modal verbs (can, will, should), use bare infinitive without 'to'

resolutions.notes: Base form 'to remember'. After modals like 'can', drop the 'to' (bare infinitive).

upchunks.teaches: 'Find out' implies discovering new information; 'know' implies existing knowledge

resolutions.notes: 'To know' is the base meaning. 'To find out' is used when the focus is on discovering/learning something new (often with questions like 'what the answer is').

upchunks.teaches: Past time markers (昨天, 上周) trigger past tense in English
Past time markers trigger past tense in English
想 has dual meaning: 'want' and 'think'. 在想 = 'thinking' (progressive aspect)

resolutions.notes: 想 has two meanings: 'to want' and 'to think'. Context determines which. Past time markers (昨天, 上周) trigger past tense. Progressive marker 在 + 想 = 'thinking'.

upchunks.teaches: With manner adverb marker 地, 很快 = 'quickly' (manner). Without it, 很快 = 'soon' (time).

resolutions.notes: 'Soon' refers to time (when something will happen). 'Quickly' refers to manner/speed (how something is done). Context and sentence structure determine which meaning.

upchunks.teaches: After modal verbs, use bare infinitive (drop 'to')

resolutions.notes: Base form 'to help'. After modals, use bare infinitive 'help'.

upchunks.teaches: 'Enjoy' emphasizes pleasure/displeasure in the activity itself; 'like' is more general preference

resolutions.notes: 'Like' is general preference. 'Enjoy' emphasizes the experience/pleasure of doing something. In negative contexts with activities, 'don't enjoy' often sounds more natural.

upchunks.teaches: 'Don't enjoy' + gerund is natural for expressing displeasure with activities

resolutions.notes: Related to 喜欢 conflict. 'Don't like' vs 'don't enjoy' - both valid, 'enjoy' emphasizes the experiential aspect.

upchunks.teaches: Third person singular (他/她) requires 'doesn't' instead of 'don't'
Third person singular (他/她) requires 'doesn't' instead of 'don't'
Past context triggers 'didn't' for all persons

resolutions.notes: Subject determines don't/doesn't (1st/2nd person vs 3rd person singular). Past context triggers 'didn't' for all subjects.

upchunks.teaches: At sentence start followed by a result clause, 这样 = 'so' (therefore/in order that)

resolutions.notes: 'Like this' = demonstrative (showing manner). 'So' = consequential (therefore, in order that). Position in sentence helps determine meaning.

upchunks.teaches: Generic/habitual context often implies plural in English
一起 (together) often implies plural friends

resolutions.notes: Chinese doesn't mark plurality. Context determines: 'give a friend' (specific single), 'with friends' (general/habitual).

upchunks.teaches: 'Fun' emphasizes enjoyment/entertainment; 'interesting' emphasizes intellectual engagement

resolutions.notes: 'Interesting' = intellectually engaging. 'Fun' = enjoyable/entertaining. Context determines which nuance is appropriate. Activities are often 'fun', ideas/topics are often 'interesting'.

linguistically_interesting: 说话 - Most complex with 5 variants, teaches gerund/infinitive triggers
想 - Dual meaning (want/think) plus tense variation
不想 - Subject agreement (don't/doesn't) and tense (didn't)
simple_standardizations: 现在 - 'now' vs 'at the moment' (just synonyms)
我想 - 'I want' vs 'I want to' (minor variation)
grammar_determined: 我 - I/me determined by English sentence position, not Chinese context
